column4: HI! I created bootable usb-drive using Create usb startup disk in an intrepid live cd. (32bit). But it doesn not work, my computer says "no bootable device found" when I select "removable" as the boot device.
That's for booting up.... at BIOS.... not Windows.
Kill the power switch on Vista.  Boot up and press <menu boot> button.  Select USB.
yes. It says "Press F9 to select first boot device after POST", then I pressed F9 and got a menu with removable, cd and hard disk.
i did select that in the bios.
That's strange.  It should be.  I know because I did that few hours ago.
How about disc?
yeah, I can boot fine from a cd rom but, i want to have a usb thumb drive on which I can also save settings and stuff like that.
| https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LiveUsbPendrivePersistent
yes. I used method 0. (but in intrepidm usb-creator is included by default and I didn't have to install it)
What Ubuntu version?
intrepid uname -r: 2.6.27-11-generic  dpkg-query -W usb-creator: usb-creator 0.1.10
Did you try different flashdrive?  I had some issues with certain flashdrives in the past.
well, no I only have one. But, I made it bootable using usb-creator before. But then, after a while, I wiped the drive; and today, I want to install ubuntu on it again. So I know the drive works.
It work... but it is probable that you wear the usb drive out already.  See if you can open inside... save files on it... etc.
yes, otherwise usb-creator couldn't save files on it (and I see that there now are fles on the drive)
I tried the Method 0 given.
I'm aware you tried the method 0.  However -- There are nothing I can do.  It worked for me.  Did you try saving files on the usb?
right-click->create document->empty file works well. Btw, the usb drive is formated to fat32? Is that ok?
I mean... save to the USB.
yes, saving to usb also works fine
If nothing work, try Method 1... and 2.
ok, I'll probably do that. The weird thing is, method 0 worked perfectly for me in the past.
